What about oppoosites attract and equals repel. Things orbit other larger bodies because they develop an equality of potential mass. While this equality is only a temporary condition as in the perihelion moment, the orbiting body becomes equal in potential mass with the primary body and they repel each other. It works on a sateliite basis such as arth and our Moon and on a Planetary basis such as with Earth and our Sun, and it apply to galactic masses as well.

Science keeps telling us about space "dust" . To date I have never heard of what this dust is composed of. Ordinary Earth dust is primarily a compound of some form of Oxygen or Carbon in a compound form. In the free space surrounding galaxies, dust would attract protons gravitationally but individually and collectively

One thing I have never heard a good explanation for is why star formation ended in eliptical galaxies. Simultaneously we are being told that star generation takes place precisely from the remains of older, large stars. And matter doesn't disappear either, so why would this process of star death and rebirth ever stop? the only real change should be that there are more heavy elements. But not by a huge amount. The Sun and our solar system contains some heavy elements, but still just trace amounts when compared to helium and hydrogen. And there is a limited time to work with here anyway. 14 billion years, give or take. How many more star deaths and rebirths could there have been time for in an eliptical galaxy.

One common thought during my studies; the vast distances and lengths of time, the sheer mass of a black hole... all of it so far away and so different from what we are accustomed to, confined to our short life on our tiny planet, all over in the "cosmic blink of an eye", our place so small it is scarcely a single subatomic particle in this grand universe, and every time I think of it I am truly humbled, for I truly cannot conceive of its beauty and depth.

The Hubble Space Telescope opened us up to distances and accuracy of measurement that the human mind truly cannot comprehend.  Sure, we can parrot distances in the Billions of Light Years but "knowing" is NOT "comprehending".  The human mind cannot even truly comprehend interstellar distances to our "Nearest" neighbors.  That's why our Science Fiction shows and movies use outrageously advanced technology that we can't actually comprehend either.  We will be extinct Millions of years before we reach Star Trek technology.  So cool to think about though!

Maybe then they thought galaxies where like how we think universes are now. There is only 1, and others are just  parallel and out of sight.... Now we think there is 1 universe... But what if the distances between them are so great that there hasn't been enough time to see them. Like a star being born across the universe. Right now its just gas to us because its the past, but by the time the light reaches us... we would have already flickered out of existence. And that their is a process that governs how universes are born, a property of space-time that is still unknown... like quantum physics is almost irrelevant at large scales and GR is almost irrelevant at small scales... the larger the quantity of space-time the different properties it exhibits... So maybe the bends in space-time get so great that the amount of energy stored is enough to convert to matter through a process and thus a universe is born. Like the distance is the transition from a digit in a sequence of irrational numbers or the dynamics of the quantity of space-time might change things. Like how we stand on earth and earth looks flat, but the ground is rough, and farther out it is spherical, its just where you look at different scales... What I find fascinating about galaxy collisions is that gravity is a big component of them. On the scale of human beings, gravity during collisions is negligible, so we can have an intuitive idea of how they work. But with entire galaxies, gravity is a much more noticeable force, and the way they "crash" into each other...seems so bizarre!

One of the consequences of insight into the structure of the universe is a feeling of disconnectedness. In the past, creation stories and geocentric assumptions placed us firmly in the center of a functioning mechanism. We were small but we felt we were watched after. The world was mysterious, but we were a thing apart from it. Now we have been thrown out of the nest and left to wander and find our own place, and the mysteries just go deeper and deeper.

I am happy to see the episodes of this crash course improve a lot. I really love the discussion on stars and galaxies and clusters. However, I am curious why certain words are used in this episode. I am curious why using words like "galaxies are cannibals" and "they eat each other" and the idea that the universe is "creation" is used in this video. Shouldn't words with less connotation be used? Shouldn't words like "conjoin" or "meet" or "envelop" be used over words like "cannibal" and "eat?" And why, in a science video, is the universe being called "creation?" Isn't that implying that someone created it, and therefore stepping outside of the science of this video?
